article:
I grew up knowing I was different, and I hated it. I was born with a deformed( )lip. When my schoolmates asked,"What happened to your    _  ?" I'd tell them
I'd fallen and  cut  it on a piece of glass. Somehow it
seemed more  _  to have suffered an accident than to have
been born  _  . I was sure that no one outside my family could love
me, or  _  like me. Then I entered Mrs.Leonard 's
second-grade class. Mrs.Leonard was pretty, with shining brown hair and warm,
dark,  _  eyes. Everyone respected her. But  _  came to love her more than I did. And for a  _  reason. The
time came for the  _  tests given at our school. I could only
just hear out of one ear, and was not about toreveal something else that would single me out as different. So I    _  . The " whisper test"  _  each child to go to the classroom
door,  _  sideways, close one ear with a finger,  while  the teacher whispered something from her desk, which the child  _  . Then the same for the other ear. Nobody checked how tightly the  _  ear was covered, so I only  _  to block mine. As  usual  I was the last. But all through the testing I  _  what Mrs.
Leonard might say to me. I know fromprevious years that the teacher     _  things like "
The sky is blue." I turned my bad ear toward her, covering the other just
enough to be able to hear. I waited and then came the seven words that changed
my life forever. Mrs.Leonard said  _  , "I wish you were my
little girl."          (292words)
